Did you know? 1. Compared to women, men are more likely to be overweight 2. Men are twice as likely to have hearing loss 3. Heart disease is the leading cause of death in men 4. Men under 55 are more prone to hypertension than women 5. Men have a 1 in 2 chance of developing cancer during their lifetime 6. Men are more likely to develop mouth cancer Source: St. Luke's Health #MensHealthMonth is held in June each year to promote awareness about #MensHealth, and encourage them to prioritize their mental and physical #wellbeing, as well as address the challenges faced by men. As part of our #WomensMonth campaign, we want to provide women with the knowledge they need to make informed decisions on their health. As many women know, we know our bodies better than anyone. But what you may not know are the different sets of symptoms women experience before a heart attack that vary from what men might experience. Knowing the symptoms can make all the difference in accurately spotting a heart attack before it strikes. Discover more life-saving insights and download our Women's Heart Health overview: https://lnkd.in/gaB5gjyu #womenshealth #heartattack

This week, June 10-16, is Men's Health Week! At ACESWorld, we work to promote health equity through many of our projects. While there are many issues for women in #healthequity, health equity is also an issue for men! Men generally report poorer health outcomes than women across many indicators. This includes heart disease, cancer, lung disease, stroke, and diabetes. These #disparities can be multifaceted, influenced by factors like race, socioeconomic status, and cultural attitudes towards health and wellness. During this week, let's remember to #advocate for men's physical, mental and emotional health, and recognize the worse health outcomes they face, and how various stakeholders can help support them in their health! #FollowUs to keep up with different health issues men face this week! #MensHealthWeek

And you might be at even higher risk if you: ‚Ä¢ Are over age 50 ‚Ä¢ Smoke ‚Ä¢ Have a slim, thin body ‚Ä¢ Have family members who had osteoporosis ‚Ä¢ Do not get enough weight-bearing exercise, such as walking ‚Ä¢ Drink alcohol (more than 3 drinks a day) ‚Ä¢ Have certain other medical conditions or take certain medicines for a long time Take steps now to #KnowYourBones early on and help reduce your risk of developing osteoporosis later. In the US, cardiovascular disease, or CVD, is the leading cause of death for women, and it also accounts for at least a third of the women's health gap. McKinsey Health Institute's latest report highlights how a lack of data and inequities between women and men in care delivery and efficacy have contributed to this disparity for over a century. Alongside my colleague Megan Greenfield, Ph.D. and leaders of the American Heart Association, we identify the actions needed to improve women's heart health, which could unlock at least 1.6 million years of higher-quality life and boost the US economy by $28 billion annually by 2040. Read the report, developed in collaboration with the American Heart Association's Go Red for Women movement: https://lnkd.in/dnV4Pgqq #WomensHealth #HeartHealth #HealthEquity #CloseTheWomensHealthGap

McKinsey Health Institute latest report in collaboration with the American Heart Association's Go Red for Women movement highlights the importance of accounting for sex and gender based differences in research so they emerge sooner, can be addressed and ensure better health outcomes. The report noted: "The understanding of biological differences is expanding, but major knowledge gaps still exist. Heart health‚Äîor lack thereof‚Äîaffects not only the cardiovascular system but the whole body, including the gastrointestinal, immune, musculoskeletal, neurological, pulmonary, and renal systems. For example, midlife hypertension is associated with an approximately 60 percent increased risk of all-cause dementia, and systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure greater than 160 millimeters of mercury) is associated with an approximately 25 percent increased risk of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease. Women go through unique stages of life characterized by fluctuating levels of estrogen (such as puberty and menopause) and additional physiological stress on the body (such as pregnancy). With the increasing prevalence of CVD in women, novel sex-related risk factors should be considered in combination with behavioral, environmental, and social factors to guide its early prevention, diagnosis, and treatment in women across all stages of life. There‚Äôs ample opportunity for research into better understanding the links between menstruation and the overall health of a woman. With greater knowledge and treatment options, women can embark on a lifelong journey to view their heart health more holistically." Good News! My Normative can help! Curious?
